text.p: These are significant stories in the Nigerian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Nigeria inagurates a 14-man committee to formulate new defence policy that will stress self-reliance in the face of present unfriendly posture of the West towards the nation.
- Canadian oil company Abacus Resources signs joint venture agreement with indigenous Nigerian oil firm Optimium Petroleum Development to explore concession block 310 in the Benin basin.
- Nigerian Liquefied Natural Gas Company, which is handling the nation"s $4 billion gas project approves appointment of Shell executive Steven Ollereanshaw as new chief executive.
- Federal government considers 20 banks to take over accounts of its ministries and agencies worth 133.5 billion naira following divestment of retail banking by central bank.
- The much-publicised 200 percent increase in domestic air fares fails to take off as airline operators appear to have soft pedalled so as not to confront the government.
- WEMA Bank, one of Nigeria's top 10, says it is suspending pay rise and allowances in order to raise its capital base to the new level of 500 million naira required by government.
- Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group meeting in London on Monday deadlocked on whether to press for further sanctions against Nigeria or recommend its re-admission to the group.
- Port Harcourt oil refinery in the southeast was shut down at the weekend for technical defects, oil sources say.
- Shipping activities rise at Tin Can Island port in Lagos.
- Businessmen to drill finance minister Anthony Ani at a three-hour session on the 1997 fiscal budget next week.
